Application_Facts: Kemenczei claimed persecution due to Roma ethnicity in Hungary; RPD found legislative efforts sufficient but did not assess operational effectiveness against fascist violence
Claimant_Status: Roma ethnic minority member, refugee claimant
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to analyze operational effectiveness of state protection measures
Evidence_Used: Hungary’s legislative efforts to protect minorities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis regarding enforcement and effectiveness of laws against fascist violence
Outcome: Federal Court quashed the RPD decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of RPD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Convention refugee and person in need of protection criteria
Decision_Rationale: RPD's finding of adequate state protection was unreasonable due to lack of analysis on real-world enforcement and protection from non-state actors
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board committed a reviewable error in assessing the applicant's refugee claim
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible by the Board
Evidence_Type: Evidence regarding risks to returning failed refugee claimants in Sri Lanka
Legal_Provision: Standard of review: reasonableness for findings of fact and credibility; correctness for questions of law
Application_Error: Alleged failure to address risks to returning failed claimants; challenged burden of proof language
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to factual and credibility findings
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness for factual findings, correctness for legal questions
Application_Factor: Burden of proof on applicant, credibility of testimony

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection and procedural fairness
Governing_Law: Charter of Rights and Freedoms (implied for procedural fairness)
Application_Facts: Two Roma families fled Hungary due to persecution and sought refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Excessive documentation demands
Insufficient reasoning
Failure to provide transparent and intelligible analysis
Evidence_Used: Evidence of systemic failure of Hungarian state to protect Roma citizens
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inadequate consideration of country condition evidence
Lack of proper assessment of available state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable findings made by the Board
Failure to justify negative credibility conclusions
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claims rejected by the Board
Outcome: Remanded for redetermination by a different Board Member
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of decision
New hearing ordered
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard of review
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to conduct transparent, intelligible analysis of current state protection; credibility findings were unreasonable
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Violation_Type: Failure to distinguish persecution from discrimination
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, SC 2001, c 27
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, SC 2001, c 27
Application_Facts: Applicants are Roma citizens of Hungary who claimed persecution and lack of state protection in their home country; sought refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Errors in credibility assessments
Failure to properly evaluate key incidents
Inadequate reasoning on state protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Key incidents dismissed or not properly evaluated
Reliance on unreliable credibility determinations
Credibility_Assessment: Board made unreasonable credibility findings
Failed to provide sufficient reasons for disbelieving claimants
Outcome: Federal Court allowed the application, set aside the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Re-examination of claims by a differently constituted Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution
State protection analysis
Credible evidence standard
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was unreasonable due to flawed credibility analysis, misapplication of persecution standard, and inadequate assessment of state protection
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Legal_Issue: Application of legal tests for state protection and internal flight alternative (IFA)
Evidence_Assessment: Board failed to consider broader context of state protection and dual citizenship
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must rebut presumption of state protection
Credibility_Factor: Claimant's fear of persecution in France and Syria
Legal_Rule: State protection is presumed unless rebutted; IFA requires no serious persecution risk and reasonable possibility of refuge
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of state protection, no viable internal flight alternative
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim not properly assessed due to flawed reasoning
Key_Evidence_Considered: Financial considerations in IFA analysis, dual citizenship status
Legal_Framework: Domestic immigration law, UN Refugee Convention
Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside, case remitted for redetermination

Legal_Provision_Violated: Principle of Procedural Fairness in Refugee Protection Division proceedings
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 101(1)(a)
Application_Facts: Applicants' refugee claims were dismissed based on perceived lack of evidence rebutting the presumption of state protection
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to question applicants about key documentary evidence; did not allow response to adverse information
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence submitted by applicants, hearing transcripts, RPD decision reasons
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD inadequately addressed contradictory evidence provided by applicants
Remedy_Sought: Remittal to a differently constituted RPD for redetermination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness under administrative law
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with respect to procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: RPD breached procedural fairness by failing to properly consider evidence and permit applicant response

Violation_Type: Failure to rebut presumption of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Ms. Rangel Macias, a Mexican lawyer and human rights activist, claimed refugee status in Canada due to threats received in Mexico; she approached neighborhood police but did not pursue further state protection measures
Claimant_Status: Mexican national, lawyer, human rights activist
Procedural_Issue: Failure to exhaust all available avenues of state protection in home country
Evidence_Used: Credible testimony of applicant, limited engagement with law enforcement in Mexico
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence demonstrating exhaustion of state protection options in Mexico
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant was found credible by the Board
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear and convincing evidence to rebut presumption of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board reasonably concluded applicant failed to take reasonable steps to access state protection in Mexico despite credible claims
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in rejecting the applicants' claim based on identity?
Crimes.Outcome: Board's decision overturned, case sent back for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Minor inconsistencies in testimony were deemed significant by the Board
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence without supporting documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to establish identity due to lack of documentation
Crimes.Application_Error: Overly strict assessment of minor inconsistencies
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of identity documents and reliance on oral testimony
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court under IRPA and Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide acceptable identity documentation
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to meet documentary requirements under immigration law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants provided no documents, relied on testimonial evidence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board rejected claim due to insufficient proof of identity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Minor inconsistencies affected credibility
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Acceptance of claim based on testimonial evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-determination by a different Board member
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable justification for lack of documents under s.106

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility assessment based on testimonial inconsistencies
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in rejecting the applicants' identity based on minor inconsistencies in testimonial evidence?
Crimes.Outcome: Board's decision overturned, case referred for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Minor inconsistencies in testimony (e.g., house color, material) deemed overly significant despite alignment in key areas
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence; no official documents provided
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Lack of Somali identity documents and use of fraudulent German passports
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of fraudulent passports and minor testimonial discrepancies
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under IRPA s.72 and Federal Courts Act s.18.1
Crimes.Application_Error: Overly microscopic examination of minor inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Possibility of translation issues affecting testimony
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable possibility of truth in testimonial evidence when documents are unavailable
Crimes.Application_Factor: Reliance on oral testimony due to lack of documentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for re-determination by a different Board member
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of fraudulent German passports to enter Canada

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Pervasive gang violence, lack of state protection
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to ongoing gang threats
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient and credible evidence of assault and state failure
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible applicant account

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Pervasive gang control, history of violence
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm if returned
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Direct threats to life and safety
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of threats and fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent and plausible narrative

Crimes.Dispute_Type: State protection failure for victims of gang violence
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Board failed to properly analyze state protection
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Refugee claim at port of entry or inland
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Inadequate state protection against gang violence

Violation_Type: Failure to apply proper legal standard
Legal_Provision_Violated: Presumption of truth in refugee claims
Obligation to consider evidence as presented
Application_Facts: Mahmud claimed persecution in Bangladesh and applied for refugee status; CRDD denied claim due to alleged lack of corroboration and inconsistencies in letters
Procedural_Issue: CRDD focused on omissions in supporting letters rather than their content, contrary to legal precedent
Evidence_Used: Letters from family and community members
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Perceived gaps in documentary evidence used improperly to undermine credibility
Credibility_Assessment: CRDD improperly assessed credibility by dismissing evidence based on form rather than substance
Outcome: Federal Court set aside CRDD's decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a new hearing
Legal_Standard_Applied: Applicant's allegations presumed true unless contradicted by evidence
Decision_Rationale: CRDD erred by not considering the content of supporting documents and violating established credibility assessment principles

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to domestic abuse; Board rejected claim based on credibility, delay, and state protection issues
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider PTSD effects on credibility
Dismissal of delay without explanation
Lack of proper assessment of state protection
Evidence_Used: Evidence related to state protection availability
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ignored key evidence on state protection
No consideration of trauma impact on consistency
Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility findings made without considering psychological effects of trauma (PTSD)
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim after related appeals
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to apply Gender Guidelines, did not justify treatment of delays, and unreasonably assessed state protection

Crime_Name: Refugee Claim Based on Spousal Abuse
Application_Facts: The applicant suffered spousal abuse from 1995 to 2003 but never sought state protection, citing societal stigma and emotional dependence. Her mother intervened in 2003, providing support and moving her to Canada.
Claimant_Status: Applicant claiming refugee status due to spousal abuse
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence suggesting Korea's state protection was ineffective
Decision_Outcome: RPD found state protection in Korea adequate; application dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Burden of proving non-existent or inadequate state protection lies with the applicant
Decision_Rationale: Subjective reluctance (e.g., stigma, emotional dependence) insufficient to establish unavailability of state protection; state structures in Korea deemed adequate

Mitigating_Factors: Police provided advice to report future incidents, referral to crisis desk
Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk due to domestic context
Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable findings by tribunal
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 96; Presumption of State Protection

Aggravating_Factors: Repeated incidents, lack of effective intervention
Mitigating_Factors: Police response included referrals and advice to report further incidents
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient for review, insufficient to rebut presumption
Evidence_Type: Applicant testimony, documentary evidence of reporting
Credibility_Assessment: Accepted with some reservations by tribunal
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96; Women's Protection Principles in International Law

Sub_Crime_Type: Marital Rape within Domestic Violence Context
Aggravating_Factors: Occurred within coercive domestic relationship, underreporting due to fear
Mitigating_Factors: Existence of legal framework and new laws addressing domestic violence
Evidence_Sufficiency: Limited direct evidence, based on testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Considered but not sufficient to overturn state protection presumption
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 97(1); CEDAW, Istanbul Convention principles

Aggravating_Factors: Part of pattern of coercive control, removal of children without consent
Mitigating_Factors: No evidence of harm to children, possible civil custody dispute element
Credibility_Assessment: Accepted as plausible but not determinative
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96; Hague Convention principles on child abduction

Dispute_Type: Credibility of applicant in refugee claim
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's credibility finding was unreasonable
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding due to inconsistencies in testimony regarding persecution and religious knowledge
Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, claimed religious belief and practice
Legal_Provision: Section 97 or 98 of IRPA (basis for refugee protection)
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution for Christian beliefs in China
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in key aspects of the applicant's testimony
Application_Error: None found; Board's decision upheld as reasonable
Evidence_Ignored: Possibly trivial religious knowledge, though court criticized overemphasis
Legal_Standard: Standard of review: reasonableness with high deference
Application_Factor: Applicant's limited knowledge of Christianity and inconsistent statements about being sought by authorities
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed, judicial review denied

Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in rejecting the applicant's refugee claim under sections 96 and 97 of the IRPA
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 96 and 97
Outcome: Federal Court dismissed the application, upholding the RPD's decision
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found insufficient evidence of sustained or systemic persecution; credibility not explicitly challenged but claim deemed unsubstantiated
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, country condition reports, single incident of harm
Legal_Provision: Section 96 (Convention refugee), Section 97 (Person in need of protection) of IRPA
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of FGM for daughters and harm from husband's family upon return to Guinea
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence of future risk or past persecution beyond isolated incident, husband’s ability to provide protection
Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), reviewed by Federal Court
Assessment_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution based on Convention grounds; risk to life or cruel treatment
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court in reviewing RPD decision
Application_Factor: Country-specific risks, family protection dynamics, prior incidents
Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed; no refugee status granted

Violation_Type: Failure to exhaust state protection avenues
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 96 or 97
Governing_Law: IRPA, Canadian jurisprudence on refugee claims and state protection
Application_Facts: Ms. Camacho fled spousal abuse in Venezuela and Trinidad without seeking police or state protection
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with domestic protection avenues in country of origin and transit
Procedural_Issue: Failure to demonstrate exceptional circumstances justifying non-exhaustion of state protections
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of state resources in Venezuela and Trinidad, claimant's testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of objective evidence supporting ineffectiveness of state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Claimant's doubts about state protection deemed objectively unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Board's rejection of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for availability and effectiveness of state protection
Decision_Rationale: In functioning democracies, claimants must exhaust state protection unless exceptional circumstances exist; none were proven here

Application_Facts: Mexican citizen claiming refugee status due to union-related harassment
Procedural_Issue: Assessment of Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
Evidence_Used: Evidence showing no significant risk of persecution in Mexico City
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Board's decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision through judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities
Decision_Rationale: Mexico City was found to be a safe IFA with adequate state protection and no likely risk of persecution

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish nexus to Convention grounds
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Allegations of verbal threats and financial exploitation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged, but evidence deemed insufficient
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low perceived risk due to available state protection
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of legal frameworks and NGOs in Guyana
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Refugee Convention

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Verbal abuse and threats (no physical harm)
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove lack of state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported elder abuse, no physical injury documented
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible allegations but insufficient corroboration on state protection failure
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Moderate personal risk, low systemic risk
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Vulnerability due to age, familial abuse
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Availability of legal remedies and NGOs

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection in Guyana
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to seek help from available NGOs or police
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unavailability of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to access available resources undermines claim
Crimes.Legal_Rule: State protection must be clearly unavailable despite legislative frameworks
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to elder abuse
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of legal frameworks, NGO services, localized police indifference
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence on state mechanisms
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question and overturning of decision

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove lack of state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Allegations of financial exploitation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plausible but not substantiated with evidence of systemic failure
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Personal financial harm, not rising to persecution
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA, Criminal Code (theft provisions), Refugee Convention

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant proved lack of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Allegations credible but insufficient to meet legal burden
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reporting, lack of engagement with state/NGO protections
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to familial elder abuse
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to demonstrate unavailability of state protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to meet burden of proof on state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – Board considered all relevant factors
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to mixed fact and law

Application_Facts: Parmar applied as an assisted relative with a job offer but was rejected due to insufficient points, lack of relevant experience, and concerns about personal suitability.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review initiated by Parmar to challenge the visa officer's decision
Evidence_Used: Job offer, application documents, assessment of points for SVP, occupational demand, and personal suitability
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient points, lack of relevant experience, concerns about personal suitability
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility or suitability assessment by visa officer
Relief_Sought: Overturning of visa officer's rejection decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to reverse the refusal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment under Immigration Act and Regulations including point system and personal suitability
Decision_Rationale: The visa officer did not err in assessing that Parmar failed to meet the required points and qualifications; Federal Court found no error in the decision

Crime_Name: Failure to disclose marital status under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Dispute_Type: Judicial review of humanitarian and compassionate application
Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness due to inadequate reasons
Basis_of_Claim: Spouse failed to disclose marriage before obtaining permanent residency
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Sufficiency of reasons provided; failure to request detailed reasons
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard with deference to Minister
Application_Factor: Overseas H&C application subject to more deferential review
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness found

Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Dispute_Type: Judicial review of humanitarian and compassionate application
Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness due to inadequate reasons
Evidence_Type: Written correspondence (rejection based on prior misrepresentation)
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant's wife made a prior misrepresentation
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Sufficiency of reasons; failure to request further details
Application_Error: Misrepresentation by spouse affecting applicant's eligibility
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard with deference to Minister
Application_Factor: Overseas H&C application subject to more deferential review
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness found

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act violation
Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation and submission of counterfeit documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of IRPA regarding misrepresentation and inadmissibility
Crimes.Application_Facts: Counterfeit educational documents submitted for Ms. Bashir's daughter as part of immigration application
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Ms. Bashir, foreign national applying with family member
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: N/A - application refused prior to residency grant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Material misrepresentation through counterfeit documents, regardless of intent
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer provided procedural fairness via fairness letter and opportunity to respond
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ms. Bashir provided no evidence to refute knowledge of document falsity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of ignorance not supported by evidence, credibility undermined
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application refused due to inadmissibility under IRPA
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn of refusal and approval of application
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Misrepresentation found on record; procedural fairness upheld

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration application refusal based on fraud
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer’s refusal due to misrepresentation was reasonable and procedurally fair
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of ignorance not credible due to lack of supporting evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (counterfeit educational documents)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on misrepresentation leading to inadmissibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of counterfeit documents by family member affecting principal applicant
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of misrepresentation and failure to rebut concerns
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of document authenticity and materiality
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None — all evidence considered; applicant failed to provide countervailing evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Dependence on accuracy of supporting documents for family members
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal upheld; applicant remains inadmissible for two years
Crimes.Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) and Federal Court of Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of parole revocation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Prisoner's account found inconsistent with file information
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, discrepancies in statements
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Acceptance of job involving financial management contrary to parole terms
Crimes.Decision_Maker: National Parole Board and Appeal Division
Crimes.Application_Error: Claimed procedural unfairness and inadequate reasoning
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature of employment duties and compliance with conditions

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of interpretation of employment condition
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Significant discrepancies between prisoner's account and file records
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the National Parole Board to show breach
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Board has exclusive jurisdiction under CCRA s.135
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of job responsibilities involving financial management
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denied breaching condition due to misunderstanding
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, parole file documentation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and adequacy of reasons in parole revocation
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review and appeal division stage
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Decisions must be reasonable and adequately reasoned
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness and lack of sufficient reasons
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Parole officer reports, employment details

Crimes.Application_Facts: Accepted position involving financial knowledge despite restriction
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasons and procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: National Parole Board authority under CCRA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Employment contract, parole file, Board findings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Account not fully credible due to inconsistencies
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Breach established based on reliable evidence and past behavior
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: National Parole Board and Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of revocation
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Reliable evidence of access to financial information
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Board to establish breach
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Revocation permissible upon breach of condition
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Misinterpretation of condition and inadequate reasons
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official documents, Board investigation records

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of revocation decision
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Found to have provided misleading information
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Revocation allowed for breach of condition
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of employment and financial involvement
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Investigative reports, employment data

Application_Facts: Inconsistencies in POE notes, PIF, and testimony including abortion details, police detention claims, address discrepancies, hesitations during testimony, and failure to seek asylum in other countries
Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility issues due to inconsistent statements and omissions
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide consistent evidence across documents and testimony
Lack of explanation for not seeking asylum in other countries
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant's credibility lacking due to material inconsistencies and implausible claims
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Board's negative credibility finding and approval of refugee status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Persecution based on religion as grounds for refugee status
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness; Federal Court cannot substitute its opinion unless decision was perverse, capricious, or ignored material evidence
Decision_Rationale: The Board's credibility assessment was reasonable and supported by evidence; no reviewable error identified

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status based on past persecution and fear of future harm from Israeli forces and Hamas
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to address supporting documentary evidence
Misinterpretation of applicant's statement regarding 'detention'
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board did not consider corroborating documents
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility findings deemed unreasonable due to incomplete analysis
Decision_Outcome: Refused by Immigration and Refugee Board
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution
Decision_Rationale: Board's credibility analysis was flawed for failing to consider all evidence and misinterpreting applicant statements

Application_Facts: Applicant provided limited evidence of bond with child Alexander; no substantial proof of anti-Semitic persecution risk in Russia
Claimant_Status: Mikhail Anaschenko, applicant for humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed whether H&C officer properly evaluated best interests of the child and risk of persecution
Evidence_Used: Assessment of bond with child, risk of persecution in Russia
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Limited evidence of parent-child bond; lack of substantial evidence regarding anti-Semitic persecution in Russia
Decision_Outcome: H&C application rejected; judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of H&C application decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of H&C officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child, credible risk of persecution under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: H&C officer properly weighed all factors including child's best interests and risk assessment; no reviewable error found
Authority_Responsible: H&C Officer, Federal Court (for judicial review)

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed fear of persecution and abuse if returned to South Korea after a denied refugee claim.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed PRRA Officer's decision on adequacy of reasons, new evidence, and state protection.
Evidence_Used: PRRA Officer found no new evidence since abuse occurred before the refugee hearing.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No new evidence presented.
Relief_Sought: Protection from return to South Korea based on fear of persecution.
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA Officer's decision.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Under IRPA, applicants must present new evidence of risks not previously considered and demonstrate lack of state protection.
Decision_Rationale: The PRRA Officer's decision was reasonable as there was no new evidence and adequate state protection exists in South Korea.

Credibility_Assessment: positive assessment by RPD

Risk_Nature: persecution due to race and ethnicity

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Risk_Nature: discrimination based on race and ethnicity

Application_Facts: Roma family faced persecution in Hungary
Procedural_Issue: reasonableness of RPD's analysis
Credibility_Assessment: positive
Remedy_Sought: none granted
Legal_Standard_Applied: balance of probabilities
Decision_Rationale: RPD reasonably concluded inadequate state protection

Credibility_Assessment: accepted by RPD

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Crimes.Crime_Name: Police inaction or complicity in crimes against racial minorities
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Application_Facts: The Seiffert family had extensive international travel but established businesses and residences in Canada.
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet the 1095-day residency requirement due to absences
Procedural_Issue: Breach of natural justice during oral hearing, failure to properly analyze residency connections
Evidence_Used: Businesses and residences established in Canada, travel history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge focused on absences rather than Canadian connections, failed to apply Re Koo and Re Papadogiorgakis factors
Outcome: Seiffert family deemed to meet residency requirements and entitled to Canadian citizenship
Remedy_Sought: Grant of citizenship based on proper assessment of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application under Section 5(1)(c)
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with consideration of natural justice
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge erred by focusing on absences and failing to assess the applicant's overall connection to Canada, resulting in a reviewable error.

Violation_Type: Claiming refugee status without sufficient evidence of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution for attending an unregistered church in China; RPD found oral evidence not credible and no documented incidents of persecution in Guangdong Province
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged misrepresentation or exaggeration of persecution risk
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of RPD decision on credibility and evidence assessment
Evidence_Used: Oral testimony, documentary evidence regarding religious persecution in China
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documented incidents of persecution in Guangdong; insufficient corroboration of personal claims
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant's oral evidence not credible
Outcome: Federal Court dismissed the application for judicial review
Relief_Sought: Overturning of RPD's negative decision on refugee claim
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of RPD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on religion under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Rationale: Conclusion that there was no serious possibility of persecution was within the range of acceptable outcomes

Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Canadian refugee determination framework
Application_Facts: Syed faced persecution by a militant Islamic group in Pakistan; police responded but interventions were ineffective; no evidence of state complicity
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimant was outside Canada when applying for refugee status
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of administrative decision
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over CRDD decisions
Evidence_Used: Incidents of violence, police responses, CRDD findings on state willingness to protect
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide clear and convincing evidence of complete state inability to protect
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on sufficiency of state protection
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed by Federal Court
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of CRDD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the 1951 Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: Inadequate state protection does not equate to absence of protection unless there is a complete breakdown of state apparatus; police showed willingness to intervene
Authority_Responsible: Canadian Refugee Determination Division (CRDD), Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative law dispute over passport revocation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the revocation of the applicant's passport reasonable under s. 10(2)(b) of the Canadian Passport Order and s. 117 of the IRPA?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 117 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 10(2)(b) of the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant facilitated sister’s entry using a fake passport and attempted to obtain boarding pass in Tokyo
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Director to show commission of an indictable offense abroad
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant admitted knowledge of counterfeit passport but cited humanitarian motive
Crimes.Legal_Rule: It is illegal to organize, induce, aid, or abet entry of undocumented persons into Canada under s. 117 IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable and procedurally unfair revocation of passport
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of fake passport, attempt to obtain boarding pass, applicant’s knowledge
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence regarding passport use and travel attempt
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 117 IRPA, s. 10(2)(b) Canadian Passport Order

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant helped sister enter Canada using a fake passport and attempted to obtain boarding pass in Tokyo
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Canadian citizen with valid passport prior to revocation
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Sister was not a legal resident or visitor
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Use of counterfeit passport constitutes misrepresentation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness in passport revocation process
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over immigration and passport matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel records, passport documents, applicant’s statements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No denial of factual actions; motive not a defense
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant truthful about actions but motive irrelevant under law
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Commission of an indictable offense abroad under s. 10(2)(b)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Knowledge of illegality negates defense; aiding illegal entry is criminal regardless of motive
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Passport Program, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative immigration and document fraud issue
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether aiding use of a fake passport constitutes abetting illegal entry under s. 117 IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 117 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant credible but actions unlawful
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of fake passport and travel attempt
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Assisting illegal entry through fraudulent documentation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Knowledge of counterfeit nature of passport
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Abetting an indictable offense under immigration law
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of counterfeit passport to facilitate entry

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant facilitated sister’s entry using fake passport and sought boarding pass
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Canadian citizen subject to passport revocation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal authority over immigration and passports
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel plans, fake passport, applicant’s involvement
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No challenge to authenticity of evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant honest about conduct but motive not exculpatory
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Indictable offense under s. 10(2)(b) due to violation of s. 117 IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Conduct met definition of aiding/abetting under s. 117; motive irrelevant

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Violation_Type: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate grounds exemption
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant fearing return to Congo, claimed ties through employment, savings, and education
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of breach of natural justice or improper test by Immigration Officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence for employment, savings, and education claims
Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under Section 25
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient establishment in Canada demonstrated by applicant

Crime_Name: Immigration Fraud and False Refugee Claim
Violation_Type: False refugee claim, Misrepresentation in application
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to FARC threats; delayed filing for asylum in the U.S.; inconsistencies in story such as no deadline for extortion; lack of corroborating evidence
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to delayed asylum application
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent statements, lack of credible supporting evidence
Procedural_Issue: Delay in seeking protection, insufficient documentation
Evidence_Used: Testimony of applicant, documentary evidence (or lack thereof)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence, inconsistencies in narrative
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant lacked credibility based on rationality, common sense, and absence of corroboration
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by the Board
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Board's decision, reinstatement of refugee claim
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision and recognition of refugee status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution, credibility assessment using rationality and common sense
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: Delay in application undermines subjective fear; inconsistencies and lack of evidence weaken credibility; Board's conclusion within acceptable range of outcomes
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court on judicial review

Application_Facts: Applicants sought visas to attend a wedding in Canada; had employment, property, and children in Nigeria; limited travel history; sufficient financial considerations
Residency_Compliance: Applicants demonstrated strong ties to country of residence (Nigeria)
Procedural_Issue: Lack of procedural fairness; no interview offered despite concerns; failure to consider key evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer disregarded strong evidence of ties to Nigeria
Credibility_Assessment: Officer doubted return intention without adequate justification
Decision_Outcome: Visa denied based on presumed non-compliance with IRPA §20(1)(b)
Outcome: Decision found patently unreasonable; overturned on judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of visa application by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness
Procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to properly assess applicant's ties to home country and did not provide opportunity to respond to concerns

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of state protection and prospective fear
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD's assessment found unreasonable due to factual errors
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on systemic corruption and ineffective enforcement in Mexico
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of domestic abuse and threats from former employer in Mexico
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inadequate state protection despite legal reforms
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider contradictory evidence on state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of systemic corruption and lack of enforcement
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk to life
Crimes.Application_Factor: Personal risk due to gender-based violence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a new panel

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: History of domestic abuse and ongoing threats
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No recent direct contact from perpetrator
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of abusive behavior by perpetrator
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threats and history of violence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted due to gender and prior victimization
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and relationship
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit, country condition reports, police records
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible and consistent with documentary evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible; RPD’s rejection deemed unreasonable

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with protection obligations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant fled Mexico due to fear of abduction by abusive husband and former employer
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lawfully present in Canada during claim
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD failed to address evidence of systemic failures
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed credible
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient consideration of state protection gaps

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated threats and history of abuse
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Lack of recent incidents cited by RPD
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of coercive and threatening behavior
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – threats of death and bodily harm
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on past relationship and gender
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal affidavit, threat documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Chronic abuse and failure of authorities to intervene
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of protective laws in theory
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systemic lack of protection for women
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – as a woman facing domestic violence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, medical records, police reports
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible and supported by country conditions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible; RPD error in dismissal

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection in corrupt systems
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD selectively used evidence on anti-corruption efforts
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show lack of effective state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's account consistent with systemic issues
Crimes.Legal_Rule: State protection must be both available and effective
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Ineffective state response due to corruption
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Reports on corruption in Mexican law enforcement
Crimes.Defendant_Response: State protection exists due to legal reforms
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Country condition reports, expert analysis

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Principles of natural justice under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: RPD dismissed claim without proper evaluation of evidence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: RPD has authority but must act fairly
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD ignored evidence of judicial inefficacy
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: RPD failed to properly assess state protection

Violation_Type: Denial of refugee status based on credibility issues
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed political persecution in Haiti; principal applicant's testimony contained contradictions, such as obtaining a birth certificate during alleged detention
Claimant_Status: Principal applicant and spouse seeking refugee status
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent testimony by principal applicant affecting credibility
Procedural_Issue: Board disregarded corroborative evidence due to credibility concerns
Evidence_Used: Testimony of principal applicant, supporting statement from spouse
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in testimony undermined reliability of evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board found principal applicant not credible due to material inconsistencies
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision denying refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in assessing Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision fell within range of acceptable outcomes; credibility findings supported by record
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Violation_Type: Failure to meet economic establishment requirements
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 11(1) - likelihood of becoming economically established
Application_Facts: Parveen applied for permanent residence; submitted a job offer unrelated to her background in nursing; assessed as having insufficient language proficiency for intended occupation
Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residency under economic class
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of breach of procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Job offer letter, language test results, pre-refusal correspondence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration of language ability relevant to intended occupation
Relief_Sought: Quashing of refusal decision, referral back for re-determination
Remedy_Sought: Declaration of unreasonable decision, order for procedural fairness
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for administrative decisions; duty of procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded Parveen lacked sufficient language skills to become economically established in her intended occupation; no obligation to seek additional clarification; applicant had opportunity to respond to concerns

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 101(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Governing_Law: Canadian jurisprudence on standard of review and procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Gavryushenko claimed fear of persecution in Russia due to political opposition to the Chechen war and threats from fascist groups; he passed through the U.S. without seeking asylum there
Residency_Compliance: Complied with Canadian entry requirements; applied for refugee status upon arrival
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fabrication of persecution claims by the Refugee Division, despite noted candour
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide clear and unambiguous reasons for credibility findings
Inadequate consideration of post-arrival evidence
Evidence_Used: Circumstances of travel through the U.S.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal ignored relevant evidence submitted after arrival
Misinterpreted failure to claim asylum in the U.S.
Credibility_Assessment: Mixed: praised candour but ultimately found allegations fabricated without clear justification
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially rejected by Refugee Division
Outcome: Referred back for rehearing before a new panel
Relief_Sought: Quashing of the Refugee Division’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review
Rehearing of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Credibility assessment standards
Decision_Rationale: The Federal Court found the Refugee Division’s reasoning unclear and internally inconsistent, particularly regarding credibility, and failing to properly address key evidence
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Risk_Assessment: Danger to the public under s. 115(2)(a)
Credibility_Assessment: Delegate's analysis found reasonable
Reasonable assessment by Delegate

Legal_Issue: Proper consideration of evidence and procedural fairness
Outcome: Remitted for reassessment of country conditions risk

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Risk_Nature: Public danger despite no recent convictions

Credibility_Assessment: Pattern of behavior supports danger finding
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of risk upon return

Decision_Rationale: Pattern of serious criminal conduct

Dispute_Type: Deportation based on drug-related organized crime
Risk_Nexus: Link between past behavior and future danger

Crimes.Crime_Name: Using a firearm to commit an offence
Credibility_Assessment: Court found analysis reasonable

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a weapon dangerous to the public
Risk_Nature: Continuing threat due to criminal pattern

Delegate’s approach upheld

Prior_Criminality: History of criminal and gang activity
Evidence_Credibility: Accepted as part of behavioral pattern
Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable reliance by Delegate
Reliance on non-conviction incidents found reasonable

Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Violation_Type: Non-compliance with humanitarian and compassionate application requirements
Application_Facts: Ms. Jung had no family ties in Canada, limited financial stability, and alleged risk of abuse in Korea deemed comparable to general population risk
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to apply correct legal test for H&C grounds
Evidence_Used: Lack of familial and economic ties to Canada, assessment of conditions in Korea
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Credibility_Assessment: Risk of abuse not found credible or distinct from general societal conditions in Korea
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no legal error found
Relief_Sought: Allowance of H&C application to remain in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship test under Section 25(1) of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer exercised discretion reasonably within statutory framework; no error in law or fact

Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Application_Facts: Ms. Jung overstayed her visa, submitted two H&C applications, claimed fear of abuse in Korea
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to properly assess H&C grounds
Evidence_Used: Duration of overstay, lack of significant ties to Canada, country condition reports on Korea
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration of hardship or integration in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Fear of abuse not substantiated as significantly different from general risks in Korea
Outcome: Judicial review denied; decision upheld as reasonable
Relief_Sought: Permission to remain in Canada on H&C grounds
Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship under Section 25(1) of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer appropriately balanced factors and applied correct legal test; decision within permissible range

Crimes.Crime_Name: Insufficient financial or family ties to China
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate intent to depart Canada after authorized stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 197 and 200
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had low income, no significant assets, family in Canada, and limited evidence of establishment in China
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Concerns about compliance with temporary residency requirements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of strong familial or financial ties to China
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No interview conducted; assessed as not required under procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Decision made by Canadian Visa Officer abroad
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No explicit finding of misrepresentation; credibility not challenged directly
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order for re-assessment or issuance of work permit
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Onus on applicant to demonstrate intent to leave Canada post-authorized stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to demonstrate sufficient ties to home country to ensure departure from Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to demonstrate ties to home country
Crimes.Application_Facts: Low income, no assets, unmarried, family in Canada, weak connections to China
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation of social, economic, or familial roots in China
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No duty to interview where no subjective or extrinsic factors used
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Overseas visa application processed under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility finding; decision based on lack of evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Mandamus order or declaration of error
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Burden on applicant to establish likelihood of departure
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Absence of compelling ties to home country increases risk of overstay
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer at Canadian diplomatic mission

Crimes.Crime_Name: Lack of evidence of international travel
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate established pattern of compliance with immigration rules
Crimes.Application_Facts: No prior international travel history, no passport stamps or visas from other countries
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Chinese national applying for Canadian work permit
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: High risk of non-compliance due to absence of travel track record
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of previous adherence to foreign immigration laws
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No procedural unfairness in decision-making without interview
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Application assessed under Canadian consular jurisdiction
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Neutral credibility assessment; decision based on evidentiary gap
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to show intent to return home after temporary stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Lack of international travel reduces confidence in applicant's transient intent

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of visa officer's refusal based on insufficient ties to home country
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR), Sections 197 and 200
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No finding of fraud, but failure to substantiate claims of return intent
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPR s. 197(1)(a): Applicant must intend to leave Canada at the end of authorized stay
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Perceived risk of overstay due to weak home country connections
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Strength of applicant’s socio-economic and familial ties to China
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – all relevant evidence considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant bears burden of proof to show compliance with conditions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Presence of close relatives in Canada influencing migration intent

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration application refusal based on economic motives
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether financial incentives undermine assurance of departure
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer reasonably inferred higher incentive to remain illegally due to wage differentials
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to rebut presumption of potential overstay
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Consistency between declared income and actual economic behavior
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must overcome presumption of non-compliance when financial incentives exist
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unreasonableness and breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed – no legal error found
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Decision grounded in factual and regulatory considerations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 16(1)(b): Need to satisfy officer of intention to leave Canada
